section-block.rac_essential-question: What vehicles do we know about? How do they help us?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Jean Reidy, illustrated by Leo Timmers
section-block.rac_book_summary: Get ready for fun! These vehicles work hard to help the builders create a fun surprise for everyone!

section-block.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Use Ii and Jj Alphabet Cards.
section-block.rac_body-text: J is for jacket. I spy a jacket. Who can show me what I spy? Continue for both sides of the cards.
Share with children today’s story is written with a rhythm. Clap a simple three- or four-part rhythm pattern and invite children to clap it back to you.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read a story called Busy Builders, Busy Week by Jean Reidy, illustrated by Leo Timmers. Point to the letter i in the word Builders.
Pablo the Parrot thinks this story will be lots of fun to read. What silly characters do you see on the cover?
I thought of a question to keep in mind as we read. When we’re finished reading, we will try to answer it together. Ready? Listen:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What kinds of trucks do these builders use?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The builders start by mapping, measuring, and planning. Why is it good to plan before you build?
Have you seen diggers like these at work? What jobs do they do?
They have a problem. They want to move all these things. How do they solve their problem? (MB)
What funny parts and pieces do you see now? What do you think the builders are building?
I’m excited to see what the busy builders built during their very busy week. What do you see?
Let’s turn and talk about the Guiding Question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What kinds of trucks do these builders use?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, using Equity Sticks, choose two or three pairs of children to share their responses.
Possible responses:
Write and read aloud short sentences about all the ways trucks help at building sites as children contribute and watch.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do they use a tow truck?
What things can the animals ride on?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Nursery rhymes do more than entertain children—they rhyme and have rhythm. These two elements help children hear syllables and recognize the sounds phonemes make, which ultimately helps them encode, decode, blend and—read! Emphasize the rhythm or rhyme when you read a story with either or both.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: OUR COMMUNITY | Week 4: Vehicles at Work

section-block.rac_body-text: Explain that using your imagination helps you form pictures in your mind. It also helps children when they are playing with friends. Ask children to close their eyes and imagine a huge, colorful slide right in the middle of the room. What does it look like? Do you think it’s a silly thing to have in the middle of the classroom or a good thing?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to look over Busy Builders, Busy Week by Jean Reidy and illustrated by Leo Timmers. This time, we’re going to think about the Mind Builder about using imagination. As we read, look for ways the author and illustrator used their imaginations. (MB)
Clifford is excited to read this narrative. He loves stories filled with imagination!

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer the questions.
Read aloud the book and the Day 2 prompts
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Wow! Who are the builders in this story? How do you know the illustrator used his imagination when making pictures for this story? (MB)
These pages have some very silly pictures. What silly things do you see?
What could you imagine doing with that alligator shape? (MB)
How is the illustrator using his imagination on these pages? (MB)
The builders saw this plain wooden fence. They thought it was a problem. What did they do to solve it? (MB)
The builders worked hard and persisted. And now what do they have? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to sit in a circle. Remind them of the huge slide they pictured before. Ask children to pretend they are climbing the ladder and the taking turns going down the slide (one at a time around the circle). Then call out other actions that might take place at a playground for children to imagine and pretend. (MB)
Have children draw their favorite character from the book and label it. Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about how each character worked so hard to make the playground.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: There’s no doubt that imaginative play is just as important—if not more important—as traditional structured outdoor recess. Children who engage in imaginative play develop larger vocabularies earlier and begin to learn social skills such as empathy, problem solving, and acceptable interactions. (Ginsburg, 2007)

section-block.rac_top-left_header: OUR COMMUNITY | Week 4: Vehicles at Work

section-block.rac_body-text: Provide materials from the earth for children to study, such as rocks, dirt, and sand. Invite children to use a magnifying glass to study the materials.
Invite children to put a thumbs up if two words rhyme: measure and treasure; fill and spill; mash and crash; load and road; mix and fix.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we’re going to reread Busy Builders, Busy Week by Jean Reidy, illustrated by Leo Timmers. We’re also going to concentrate on how materials from the earth are used to build the playground.
Pablo knows that this book is a story, but is excited to learn about science from it.
Today, as we revisit the story, let’s try to find an answer to this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How do the builders use materials from the earth?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and use the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What materials from the earth are they collecting in the bucket?
The mixer is making cement. Cement is made from sand, little pebbles, and water that all come from the earth. Why do the builders need cement?
The elephant is spreading little pebbles for a path. Do little pebbles grow or are they part of the earth?
pages 18–19
Plants grow in the earth. Why is it nice to have plants around?
Wow! Look at that playground! Can you point to the things made from materials from the earth? Can you name them?

section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk about the Guiding Question:
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How do the builders use materials from the earth?
section.rac_body-text: Then, using Equity Sticks, choose two or three children to share their ideas about the question.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: They put water in the fountain.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to try out different writing tools. Together, write out the days of the week and point out what happens on those days in the book.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does the elephant spread little pebbles?
What kinds of earth materials does the digger move?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children may not yet be familiar with what materials come from the earth. Use this opportunity to explain what they are. Invite children to help you make a list of things that come from the earth.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: OUR COMMUNITY | Week 4: Vehicles at Work

section-block.rac_body-text: Display a set of vehicles from the block corner. Have children take turns choosing one and describing what it looks like and what they would use it for.
Invite children to put a thumbs up if two words rhyme: dig and big; plane and horn; bus and bat; fan and plan; splash and crash; chug and mug; wings and things.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to look at a poster called The Wheels on the Bus. It is a song with informational text.
Pablo can’t wait to sing and move to the song!
Busy Builders, Busy Week and The Wheels on the Bus both show how vehicles can help us.
As we read the Big Chart, let’s talk about the concept questions for the week:
What vehicles do we know about? How do they help us?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to Vehicles at Work
section.rac_body-text: Sing aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart. Then use these prompts to read and discuss the pictures on the poster together.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How do the wheels on the bus go?
When does the horn on the car go beep, beep, beep?
What sounds do the oars on the boat make?
When do the wings on the plane go swoosh, swoosh, swoosh?
What sound does the train engine make?
What sound does the bucket on the digger make?

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to pretend they are drivers. Model sitting down, putting on a seatbelt, and holding your hands out as if holding a steering wheel.
1. Drive a fire truck. Go fast but be careful!
2. Now drive a school bus. First open the door and let the children on. Drive slowly so nobody bounces up and down.
3. Then drive a digger. Mime driving slowly forward and pulling the handle so the shovel goes down and up.
Provide a writing prompt about how vehicles help in a community. Give ongoing feedback as children draw and write.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children this age enjoy movement and will actually focus better, learn more, and retain information longer if they are able to move while learning. In most classrooms, sitting is the norm. Engaging children to move as you sing songs provides the boost children need for extra mental and physical stimulation.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: OUR COMMUNITY | Week 4: Vehicles at Work

section-block.rac_body-text: Ask children to listen closely as you read so they can be ready to act out and retell the story.
Assign children a “day,” and tell them to jump up when you say it as you sing the song, “Seven Days in a Week.” Invite children to sing along with you.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to revisit the book Busy Builders, Busy Week by Jean Reidy.
Pablo knows that when he retells a story, he tells what happened from beginning to end. He’s going to listen carefully to remember so he can retell.
Now that we know what the builders are making, let’s keep in mind this question today:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What do the builders do each day?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: On Sunday, what do the builders do? Let’s pretend to write a plan.
On Monday, what vehicles do they use to move the dirt?
On Tuesday, what do the builders use the cement for? Let’s pretend to drive the mixer.
On Wednesday, where are they taking their load?
On Thursday, they are getting the road ready. Show me what the builders are doing.
Let’s pretend to plant flowers just like the builders did on Friday.
What exciting thing happens on Saturday? What was the treasure that the builders planned?
Were you able to find answers to our question?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What do the builders do each day?
section.rac_body-text: Ask children to take turns retelling what happens on certain days. Encourage them to include details.
Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, use Equity Sticks to choose two or three children to share their responses.
Possible answers:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: On Sunday, they make a plan.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about their own experience building something. Ask them what they built, and how they used their imagination before they began building.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do they stack bricks on Tuesday?
How long do you think it takes to build a real playground?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Retelling has long been used as a tool for developing comprehension, but now it is known that children who are learning a second language benefit greatly from this strategy. Retelling can be done orally, in drawing, or as reenactments. With regular story retelling, your children will notice and add more details.
